title: What makes a song to be “stuck in your head?”. How can I get over this? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have battled this malady since the first time I went to Disneyland as a kid. There, I was exposed to, “It’s a Small World After All”. Need I say more? That song is a curse. And I carried it for years, until I heard, “It’s My Party and I’ll Cry if I Want to”, cry if I want to, cry if I want to …. But that song did eradicate “Small World” from my brain. However, I’ve found that “Small World” had taken its toll on my brain. It was much bigger before the Disneyland trip. But I figured if “It’s My Party” could send “Small World” scampering, there must be other songs that will put me right. What I do now is pick an emergency “unstick song and I have it always available. I don’t know of any other way to infiltrate and conquer the stuck sound. Overriding it is the only solution I’ve found

Mpho, many years ago, I forget the song, by Lionel Richie, drove me CRAZY. I absolutely despised it. Many years before that, I was in a car being driven to Yankee Stadium, when Eight Days a Week came on, it drove me CRAZY. I absolutely loved it. From what I understand, many areas of the brain,( forum doctors correct me if I’m mistaken please) the hyppocampus, amygdila, glands releasing certain endorphins, are involved. Perhaps it depends on the song itself, or the state of mind as one was listening. If I dont like the tune, I bang myself on the head screaming, STOP IT STOP IT I CANT TAKE IT ANYMORE. If I like the tune, then full steam ahead, let it ride. Maybe its the hook. From your question, it appears you don’t like the song, as you want to get over it. Like unrequited love, it will take some time. Of course it doesnt help matters if its a song currently on the air, and cant be avoided. All I can say is time heals.

If you associate the song with someone/something then it could really dwell in your head for quite some time. Could be the lyrics that hook you, but if it’s the melody maybe it has something to do with your current mood. Could also be id its a popular song that you hear from almost everywhere it has higher chance of retaining in your head. Try listening to other music or do something to get your head out of it, like running, exercise, art or studying. In rare cases you could be in a trance. In Islam they prohibit music you know why? Dunno if you believe or not but some music induce black magic/behavioral suggestions. You know why they charm snakes by music? How certain old rituals were aided by music? Also how some people see effects in meditation music and binaural beats? Could be scary yeah but rare music are like this just be careful what you listen to.

Earworms. You don’t like earworms slinking around in your head? Still have “Brandy” and “Safety Dance” stuck in there? You know what? Embrace earworms. When you embrace an earworm for what it is, a memorable song that left a lasting impression on you, it won’t bother you anymore. If a song isn’t memorable, you’d forget it. But an earworm sneaks in without your approval, without your consent, so you resent it. Don’t. Embrace it. Like the kisses and caresses of a former lover, let it linger.

My brief advice for that matter is to listen/imagine that song in your head at its near-end. Which for some reason, you are tricking your brain to stop thinking about it that it ends there. Whenever you can, try to avoid anything that triggers you to remember that catchy song. Listen to other old music that you like that reminds you of other things (take a nostalgia trip), use it as a distraction to that catchy song. You'll get over it! Good luck, and I hope it helps! ~Eman

Hopefully, if it’s a song you love or connect with, Go with it. Enjoy and savor the words and rhythm. You can even create a new line or two yourself. If this is troubling you, change the tune. Listen to or sing one of your favorite songs and it may block out the one that is “stuck” Of course there is the dilemma that the new song will also get “stuck”! Pick a good one!

That’s what’s called an “ohr-wurm” (German for “ear-worm”). Maybe knowing what to call it will help you to lose it. Usually it goes away in couple of hours by itself. You might try playing some other music. Probably if you can play it yourself on some instrument that would help. Or some rythmic physical activity like lifting weights or jogging or climbing stairs might. My jogging song has been “Smoky the Bear” for fifty years now. For me, Smoky can annihilate any pesky ohr-wurm.

This usually happens when we don't know all they lyrics and we sing it over and over until we know the words, or make up our own that sound close enough. You can Google the lyrics or type in the song with lyrics. Once you know the words keep singing along and you will soon forget about the song playing over and over in your head.

I don’t know but I searched 5 years to find a song that went uncredited in a movie. Finally, I called into a radio show on this topic and one of the hosts did a YouTube search and found it, but it had no name. I did find out who wrote it though. It must be the rhythms triggering something in the brain.

If you associate the song with a specific event in your life, this can make a song be stuck in your head. I suggest you find another song you enjoy and listen to this song or do something else so you have to focus your mind on another activity. You could write a kind letter or email to a friend or relative.

one trick that sometimes helps, is to mentally finish the song. for example, if New YotkNew York is stuck in yoir head (start spreadin the news…) and tgat same line keeps playing, stop and let tge entite song play out. if yoi dont know it, maybe let the verse or the chorus play out. do so in a way so that ut feels like upur letting the song end.. it often helps believe it ot not

There are songs that stick in your head. The creator is not responsible for this. It is a matter of chance that a song sticks in your head. You ask, ”How can I get over this?”. My answer is why should you bother? Relax. and enjoy it. Eventually it will leave your head.

Usually, the part of a song that stays in your mind is called a hook, which is a phrase repeated a few times within the song, it could be just a piece of music, or a vocal phrase, but if it sticks with you , the writer accomplished his goal by making a memorable song. you can get over it by listening to other songs, but watch out there are plenty of hooks to catch you

What makes this is that the tune is “catchy" meaning it's easily remembered and familiar. I find a good way to get past this is to either write down the hook that is stuck, or sing it aloud to someone, thereby passing it on. Have fun!

Just give it time… after a while the song will fade away because your brain will become occupied with something else… at least, that’s how it happens with me And I wake up with a song in my head EVERY morning

Happened to me before as well! I listened to a few other songs a few times and found that the annoying one had receded into the background and because I had two or three others, none fortunately stuck in my head!!
A catchy hook or refrain I guess. Sometimes if you sing the song out loud, it stops sticking in your head!
Listen to it. Really understand what it says to you. I got bobby mcferin playing in my head all day sometimes.

For me, when a song is stuck in my head, it is often because it carries a message I am suppose to hear. So, at those times, I can google-up the lyrics and take a look at what maybe a higher part of the mind is trying to suggest to the lower-mind part.
I can not tell you the causes of it as I do not have knowledge of that, but try to listen to the whole song until the end it has helped me before.
It happens to me too , when it happens I try to occupy myself doing something that takes a lot of brain power eg. Online scrabble seems to work for me ! ( scrabble GO) from ‘ Play store'.

These kinda songs are called earworms They get stuck in your head for an insane amount of time If you wanna get over it, then try listening to another song over and over. If it doesn’t help, listen to many songs
